Following these findings, @WhipClyburn asked @CFPB to review failures by Equifax, Experian and TransUnion and address possible violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.
https://coronavirus.house.gov/news/press-releases/clyburn-cfpb-chopra-equifax-experian-transunion

Add'l data suggests the majority of disputes haven‚Äôt resulted in corrections or removal of reported errors for consumers. 
 
From 2019 to 2021, Equifax didn‚Äôt change or correct 53-57% of disputed items each year, Experian didn‚Äôt change or correct 48% & TransUnion 47-51%.

Overreliance on data furnishers‚Äîinstitutions like banks, lenders, and collection agencies that report data to credit reporting agencies‚Äîto investigate consumer disputes may also be impacting the accuracy of Americans‚Äô credit report information.

From 2019 to 2021, Equifax, Experian and TransUnion referred 61-62%, 54-56% and 80-82% of consumer disputes to data furnishers each year, respectively. 
 
@CFPB has previously cited credit bureaus for failing to identify and address unreliable data furnishers.

.@CFPB provides consumers with sample template letters to submit disputes to credit bureaus, but the credit bureaus have policies to discard disputes with similar language or verbiage‚Äîmeaning letters based on those templates may be discarded.
The top three credit bureaus also discarded at least 13.8 million dispute submissions without investigation between 2019 and 2021.

CFPB previously estimated that the top three credit bureaus received about 8M credit report dispute submissions from American consumers each year. 
 
Data obtained by @COVIDOversight found well over 14M disputes were submitted each year from 2019 to 2021.
https://www.cnbc.com/2022/10/17/transunion-equifax-experian-may-have-violated-credit-reporting-rules-rep-jim-clyburn-says.html
